title: How to Create Your Own Hand Painted Kitchen

steps.headline: For previously painted or varnished kitchens
Give the surface a good rub down with a 150 grade sandpaper.
Dust off before wiping down with white spirits on a rag.
steps.description: For wooden kitchens that have been oiled or waxed in the past

steps.headline: Give them a really good scrub using the white spirits and wire wool.
steps.description: Every square inch will need to be cleaned. You might need to scrub them a couple of times to be sure you have removed the wax or oil.

steps.headline: Use the bin primer and start painting from the top of the kitchen and working your way down.
steps.description:
Bin primer dries very fast so likewise you will need to move as quickly as you can with it. When painting the cabinet doors start with the outside first before painting the inside. Make sure to lay off the paint with brush strokes going from top to bottom, not left to right. If there are panels on the doors, then paint these before painting the surrounding door. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/dc\/Create-Your-Own-Hand-Painted-Kitchen-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Create-Your-Own-Hand-Painted-Kitchen-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/dc\/Create-Your-Own-Hand-Painted-Kitchen-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Create-Your-Own-Hand-Painted-Kitchen-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: When the bin primer has dried use the sanding sponges to rub the paint smooth, then dust down the whole kitchen with your dust brush and finally wipe it down with spirits on a rag
Use the tinted 1-2-3 primer and paint the kitchen again from top to bottom.
When the paint has dried use the 2 pack filler to fill up any little holes or dents.
steps.description: Don’t overfill because it dries very hard and can be difficult to sand back. Once it has gone hard, less than half an hour, sand the filler, dust it back then touch it up again with the 1-2-3 primer.

steps.headline: Give the kitchen 2 finish coats, for best results.
steps.description: You know the drill now, starting at the top of the kitchen and working your way down..

steps.headline: When the finish coat has dried, give it a really good rub down with the 240 grade sandpaper, then dust off and rub down with a damp rag.
steps.description: No need for spirits on your rag, just use water.

steps.headline: Use the caulk to fill any gaps you might find.
steps.description: Using a wet finger run the caulk into the gaps then wipe away any excess with a damp cloth. The caulk will need at least an hour to dry before you can paint over it again (if you are using oil based paint you’d have to leave the caulk to dry for 24 hours).

steps.headline: Apply the finish coat!
steps.description: Once more from the top down.

text:
Preparing the Surface For previously painted or varnished kitchens Give the surface a good rub down with a 150 grade sandpaper. Dust off before wiping down with white spirits on a rag. For wooden kitchens that have been oiled or waxed in the past Give them a really good scrub using the white spirits and wire wool. Every square inch will need to be cleaned. You might need to scrub them a couple of times to be sure you have removed the wax or oil. Painting Use the bin primer and start painting from the top of the kitchen and working your way down. Bin primer dries very fast so likewise you will need to move as quickly as you can with it. When painting the cabinet doors start with the outside first before painting the inside. Make sure to lay off the paint with brush strokes going from top to bottom, not left to right. If there are panels on the doors, then paint these before painting the surrounding door. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/dc\/Create-Your-Own-Hand-Painted-Kitchen-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Create-Your-Own-Hand-Painted-Kitchen-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/dc\/Create-Your-Own-Hand-Painted-Kitchen-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Create-Your-Own-Hand-Painted-Kitchen-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} When the bin primer has dried use the sanding sponges to rub the paint smooth, then dust down the whole kitchen with your dust brush and finally wipe it down with spirits on a rag Use the tinted 1-2-3 primer and paint the kitchen again from top to bottom. When the paint has dried use the 2 pack filler to fill up any little holes or dents. Don’t overfill because it dries very hard and can be difficult to sand back. Once it has gone hard, less than half an hour, sand the filler, dust it back then touch it up again with the 1-2-3 primer. Give the kitchen 2 finish coats, for best results. You know the drill now, starting at the top of the kitchen and working your way down.. When the finish coat has dried, give it a really good rub down with the 240 grade sandpaper, then dust off and rub down with a damp rag. No need for spirits on your rag, just use water. Use the caulk to fill any gaps you might find. Using a wet finger run the caulk into the gaps then wipe away any excess with a damp cloth. The caulk will need at least an hour to dry before you can paint over it again (if you are using oil based paint you’d have to leave the caulk to dry for 24 hours). Apply the finish coat! Once more from the top down.
